qas.question: What is jewish law today based on?
what does the halakha represent to orthodox judiasm?
Where were the rules about the Torah revealed to Moses by God?
How many rules are jewish law derived from?
What law is considered to be no less the word of god?
What is the commandments in the Torah based on according to Modern day Judaism?
Which literature debated the accuracy of the commandments in the Torah?
What does modern Judaism hold about the halakha?
What was given to Noah on Mt. Sinai?
Which kind of law is consider less because there is no written account?

context: According to Orthodox Judaism, <b5_0>Jewish law<b5_0/> today is based on the commandments in the <a0_0>Torah<a0_0/>, as viewed through the discussions and debates contained in classical <b6_0>rabbinic literature<b6_0/>, especially the Mishnah and the Talmud. Orthodox Judaism thus holds that the halakha <b7_0>represents the "<a1_0>will of God<a1_0/>"<b7_0/>, either directly, or as closely to directly as possible. <b8_0>The laws<b8_0/> are from the word of God in the Torah, using a set of rules also revealed by God to Moses on <a2_0>Mount Sinai<a2_0/>, and have been derived with the utmost accuracy and care, and thus the <a4_0><b9_0>Oral Law<b9_0/><a4_0/> is considered to be no less the word of God. If some of the details of Jewish law may have been lost over the millennia, they were reconstructed in accordance with internally consistent rules; see The <a3_0>13<a3_0/> rules by which Jewish law was derived.
